English translation.ã€‘Buan County Governor Kwon Ik-Hyeon Practices 'Administration by Running'Visit to Sejong Government Complexâ€¦Request for 8 strategic projects including Baeksan Holy Land constructionReporter Lee Han-shinWhile Buan-gun, Jeollabuk-do Autonomous Province is turning to an all-out war system to secure the advantageous position of securing the 2026 national budget, and local governments across the country are engaged in a fierce behind-the-scenes competition, Governor Kwon Ik-hyun visited key ministries on the 12th.On this day, Governor Kwon sequentially visited the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries, Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism, and Ministry of the Interior and Safety at the Sejong Government Complex and requested that key regional strategic projects be reflected in the national budget.This visit is intended to open the door to resolving local issues and persuade key projects that are key to creating a sustainable Buan to be reflected in the budgets of each ministry as much as possible, as each ministry is scheduled to submit its budget plan for next year to the Ministry of Strategy and Finance by the end of this month.First, Governor Kwon directly explained eight key pending projects in the fields ofâ–²carbon neutralityâ–²oceansâ–²ecologyâ–²culture to the working-level staff and suggested that they be reflected in policies.At this event, Governor Kwon explained, "Buan has sufficient capacity and foundation to proactively implement the nation's future strategies such as oceans, carbon neutrality, and ecological resources." He then presented the feasibility and urgency of promoting the project, saying, "The establishment of the Carbon Neutral Experience Center, an education and experience platform for responding to the climate crisis, the creation of Baeksan Holy Ground that inherits the spirit of the Donghak Peasant Revolution, and the establishment of the Hall of World Citizen Revolution are in line with the direction of national policy and contain the contents of expanding local resources into national values."In particular, he added, "We will further strengthen cooperation with the central government so that regional issues can be promoted as part of national policy rather than simply as local projects."He then showed meticulousness by proposing major projects for improving the regional living environment and responding to disasters, such asâ–²installation of tidal flat ecological resource conservation and tourism-linked exploration facilitiesâ–²replacement of the Gyeokpo passenger ship terminalâ–²expansion of public livestock waste treatment facilitiesâ–²comprehensive management of areas at risk of flood damage.Governor Kwon stated, "Among the three stages of government budget preparation (ministries-MOSF-National Assembly), the reason why we must prioritize the first step is because it is essential to reflect regional projects in the ministries' budget, so we will gather our administrative power to achieve the remarkable result of securing the largest national budget in history in 2026 by establishing various strategies such as making the most of our personal networks."He also emphasized, "In the future, we will further strengthen policy cooperation with related ministries and the Jeonbuk Special Self-Governing Province, and at the same time, practice 'administration that runs on its feet' centered on the field through follow-up responses at each stage of the National Assembly and the preparation of ministries."Meanwhile, at the 'May Empathy Day' event held on the 7th, Governor Kwon said, "Securing national funds is the foundation of county administration and a key driving force for fulfilling promises to the people and accelerating regional development," and ordered, "Each department should closely analyze the policy direction of the ministry and persuasively present the necessity and legitimacy of the project."ì›ë³¸ ê¸°ì‚¬ ê¸°ì‚¬ë¥¼ 'êµ¬ê¸€ ë²ˆì—­'ìœ¼ë¡œ ë²ˆì—­í•œ ì˜ë¬¸ ê¸°ì‚¬ì˜ [ì „ë¬¸]ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. 'êµ¬ê¸€ë²ˆì—­'ì€ ì´í•´ë„ ë†’ì´ê¸°ë¥¼ ìœ„í•´ ë…¸ë ¥í•˜ê³  ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ë¬¸ ë²ˆì—­ì— ì˜¤ë¥˜ê°€ ìˆì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒì„ ì „ì œë¡œ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.Megalopolis Policy and Policy Megalomaniac- Professor Lee Yang-seung of Kunsan National UniversityAhead of the June 3 presidential election, the full-scale presidential election campaign has begun. One thing to point out is that South Korea is a very strange country. People who normally have no interest in local areas and who consider local work as demotions are routinely looked down on, but when it comes to elections, they shout â€œlocal developmentâ€ and make a fuss. South Korea is a country that says to â€œrelocate incompetent employees to local areas.â€â€œMegalopolisâ€ is the alternative. Megalopolis refers to a metropolitan area. Seoul, Gyeonggi, and Incheon, that is, the metropolitan area, are in fact one megalopolis. With a population of about 26 million, more than half of the entire population of South Korea, many people think that in order to achieve balanced development, everything in Seoul should be relocated to local areas. This is the background of the 14 local innovation cities that Roh Moo-hyun proposed. They ended in failure. They are not innovation cities, but ghost cities. On Fridays, they all leave like the tide receding.The reason for the failure is that it was divided into small pieces in a â€˜sharingâ€™ manner. In that case, â€˜agglomeration benefitsâ€™ do not occur. â€˜Agglomeration benefitsâ€™ are benefits that are obtained when people gather together. To make it easier, think about why people want to live in a city. There are various reasons. Consumption diversity, jobs, cultural needs, etc. Those are agglomeration benefits. The innovative cities of Roh Moo-hyun are social costs. That is why they are criticized as strategic cities for election purposes.The â€˜strategic concentrationâ€™ proposed by former Peopleâ€™s Power Party leader Han Dong-hoon is correct. In other words, in order to achieve the â€˜agglomeration effectâ€™, several cities need to be selected and concentrated. The most ideal would be to select a specific city and grow it to overcome the Seoul-dominant system. However, given the regional sentiment in Korea, that proposal will absolutely not be accepted. That is why we need to foster megalopolises by region in order to maximize agglomeration benefits.One thing to point out bluntly is that there is currently no true megalopolis in Korea other than Seoul. Seoul has too much. The president and the members of the National Assembly are all in Seoul. The region with the largest GDP is also in Seoul. Gyeonggi-do is said to have the largest population, but it serves as Seoulâ€™s bed town. This is because of Seoulâ€™s expensive housing prices.Almost all of the headquarters of large corporations are in Seoul, more than 70% of South Koreaâ€™s deposits are in Seoul, most of the public broadcasting, cable TV, and major media outlets are in Seoul, all of the prestigious universities that are career-oriented are in Seoul, and most of the high-speed rail terminals are also in Seoul. Above all, the most absurd thing is Seoulâ€™s soul culture. If you watch a drama based on a military coup, youâ€™ll see a line like, â€œIf you catch Seoul, everyone else will follow.â€ This is an expression that refers to Seoul as â€œoldiesâ€ and the provinces as â€œlittle punks.â€Which city in the US would be the â€œoldiesâ€ in the Korean way of thinking? The largest city is New York. However, the political center is Washington, D.C. The state that is good to live in and has the largest regional GDP is California. Its central city is LA. The city that continues the tradition in the inland of the US is Chicago. The region where companies gather is Texas. The place that the rich like is Florida.In Korea, everything is Seoul. So â€˜Seoulâ€™ is â€˜soulâ€™. It is the spirit of Korea. The name â€˜Seoul Special Cityâ€™ is also strange. If it is â€˜Seoul Metropolitanâ€™, it should be â€˜Seoul Metropolitan Cityâ€™. And why is the only city in Seoul with a two-digit phone code (02)? It is not a coincidence that Cho Yong-pilâ€™s â€˜Seoul Seoul Seoulâ€™ and Patty Kimâ€™s â€˜Seoul Hymnâ€™ are songs.The most realistic way to achieve balanced development is not to single out a city to stimulate public sentiment, but to categorize development areas centered on rivers. For example, Seoul is part of the Han River region. Koreaâ€™s four major rivers are not â€˜Han River, two rivers, three rivers, four riversâ€™, but â€˜Han River, Nakdong River, Geum River, and Yeongsan Riverâ€™. The other rivers, except for the Han River, do not receive much attention. First, we need to create development projects that connect the rivers from the mouth to the middle and upper reaches.The Geum River mouth reaches Gunsan and Saemangeum, the middle reaches Buyeo, Gongju, Sejong, and the metropolitan city of Daejeon. Everyone drinks the same Geumgang River water. It determines the functions of the connected cities along the river. Gunsan and Saemangeum, which are at the estuary, are industrial, Buyeo and Gongju, which are in the middle reaches, are tourist destinations, and Sejong and Daejeon are administrative and consumer markets. In particular, the Geumgang region has great potential to grow into a megalopolis. This is because of its proximity to the metropolitan area. There is not much geographic space that can be developed in the oversaturated metropolitan area. If southern Gyeonggi and the Geumgang region are connected, it can have a great integration effect.The Nakdonggang and Yeongsangang regions can also be developed in a similar way. Major cities should be grouped together around the river to build transportation and tourism infrastructure, and administrative districts should be integrated and simplified as much as possible. If administrative districts are divided too much, effectiveness is reduced. If the licensing entity changes and the interests of politicians are conflicting, development is virtually impossible. Even if the Saemangeum region is integrated into one, it is said that it will be divided into three parts: Gunsan, Gimje, and Buan. If licensing is issued separately for each city and county, development is impossible, let alone planning.Of course, if the administrative districts are divided well, the politiciansâ€™ â€˜gaoâ€™ will be saved in relation to permits. However, development may be delayed because of the politiciansâ€™ â€˜gaoâ€™. Many people misunderstand Megalopolis. They are the megalomaniacs who are delusional about policy. yslee1992@kunsan.ac.kr*Author/Lee Yang-seung, Professor, Kunsan National UniversityA scholar who studies international economy, game theory, and regional development strategies. He is currently a professor in the Department of Trade at Kunsan National University. Previously, he researched and lectured on â€˜gamingâ€™ at the Department of Economics at the University of Alberta in Canada and worked as a research fellow at the Korea Construction Industry Research Institute.Born in Namwon, Jeollabuk-do, he graduated from Jeonju Hanil High School and Jeonbuk National Universityâ€™s College of Commerce. Afterwards, he moved to the United States and studied statistics and economics at North Carolina State University, where he received a master's degree, and received a doctorate in economics for his research on industrial organization and game theory at the University of Kansas.His books include 'Metro Economy (Timeline)', 'Wild Game Theory (Park Young-sa)', 'Introduction to Trade (co-authored, Doo Nam)', 'Construction Industry in Cultural Lag (co-authored, Korea Construction Industry Research Institute)', etc., and he has 36 independent academic papers.ê¸°ì‚¬ì œë³´ ë°
